source.author: Entwisle, T.J.
source.title: Ferns and allied plants (Psilophyta, Lycopodiophyta, Polypodiophyta)
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: Modified from: Entwisle, T.J. (1994). Ferns and allied plants (Psilophyta, Lycopodiophyta, Polypodiophyta). In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Foliage leaves clearly of two sorts, 2 dorsal rows flattened into one plane; stems prostrate or procumbent; alpine
Foliage leaves similar, overlapping and spirally arranged; at least fertile branches erect

Plants usually less than 30 cm tall; stems erect or trailing, much-branched; leaves all alike, spreading and curved upwards; strobili few, 2–5 cm long, carried above foliage leaves, often on almost leafless stalks; alps and subalps
Plants 30–100 cm tall; main stem rigidly erect then much-branched; leaves very small, often of more than one sort; strobili numerous, 1–2 cm long, on tips of ultimate branches; lowlands
